bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 3, 1901

div1.p: Reed mentions the sixth case of experimental yellow fever, and that volunteers have gone thirty-five days without contracting yellow fever in the infected clothing test. He describes the condition of a yellow fever case and an experiment with blood injection.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 3, 1901
div1.opener:
Did you
get the
check?
a kiss for
Doogy.
Columbia Barracks,
January 3, 1901,
My precious Oomsey;
div1.p:
Why didn't
you have a letter ready
when the mail came, on
yesterday? was it that
you forgot to write, you
sweet Miss Gouty, in the
midst of your “teas” &
theatres? Or did that silly
rumor that poor, good
old Beechner hurried-
ly carried to you about
my coming completely
upset you? I had a
letter from Mr Meyers
on yesterday, in which
he stated that a rumor
had reached the museum
that I would be home, last
Saturday, and that Beechner
had unfortunately hurried
over to tell you! wasn't
that a perfect shame!
and how could such a
report have been carried
to Washington? I can't imag
ine how such a thing could
have happened? Or did
you, like a sensible woman,
pay no attention to it?
I sincerely hope so, or
my babies must have been
very much disappointed-
I am rejoiced, sweetheart,
that the time is rapidly
slipping by, when we will
, start home- I am, every
day, now engaged in writing
our paper for the Congress
and will have it in shape
in about 10 days more- Then
I shall take it very easy
till the time comes to read
it- I don't know how I shall
feel when I stand before
an audience of several
hundred foreigners, but guess
that I can manage to hold
my own- About 1000 del-
egates are expected, but
I don't think that so many
will come -- we have had
our 6th case, to-day - and
this last one has proven
of more interest to me than
any of the preceding, as we
infected him with mosqui-
toes that had bitten one
of our own cases, and a
mild one at that- Again
it shows so clearly that
the mosquitoes cannot
infect under 12 days; at
least not at this season
of the year- He has all of the
typical symptoms of a
well marked case and will
be seen by the experts to-
morrow or next day- The
men who have been now 35
nights in our infected clothing
building are perfectly well!
And yet there will be fools
who will shall say that unpack-
ing an old trunk, or opening
a closet where some suppos-
edly infected garment hangs,
will always convey yellow
fever! What a world this
is anyway in which we
live! It will be as hard
for Gen. Sternberg to give up
the infected clothing theory
as anyone else, for he has
in his various writings
espoused it as one of the
things facts that were well
established! But we have
already knocked this theory
to simple Smithereens!
Hurrah! Hip! Hurrah!!
I have a long letter from Dr
Woodhull in which he tells
me that before formulating
finally a theory, I should care-
fully read this mans account
of an epidemic on board
some ship, & that man's
(Tom, Dick, or Harry's) ac-
count of an outbreak of
yellow fever on the Mary
Jane at Barbadoes, & c, & c,
When I recall that the doc-
tor still is not convinced
that mosquitoes convey
Malaria, I shan't waste
any words, trying to per-
suade him as to how
yellow fever is propagated-
we will put the facts be-
fore him and others, & if they are
not then convinced, nothing
would convince them.
The mode of propagation of
yellow fever is no longer
a theory - it is a fact! and
a well-established one at
that! But why am I writing
all of this to my darling wifie?
I suppose that because she
has become so much in-
terested in this work of
her dear old Mr Mantee!
and that I must have an au-
-dience!! By the way, the cake,
old Mother Goose's- I beg par-
don- Mother Greer's cake is
now in Havana & I will
get it tomorrow! my! won't
I enjoy it? no danger of
gout here, lovie, dear! And it
has just occurred to me that
it will be perfectly delight-
ful here after to sit up and
leisurely imbibe all of the
mixture of old Crow & Mint!
For of course, my sweet wifie
musn't take even one drop!
oh no! lovie, dear, “Tanglefoot
is very, very injurious to the
gouty constitution! Dr Nash
has already told you that!
of course, sweet scholar from
Annapolis can have a small
thimbleful occasionally! But the
large, crisp, gurgling, “gulps”
will be “me own” & none
others!! He! He! Ha! Ha! Ho! Ho!
Good-night, you sweet joys!
Pleasant dreams of old Mr
mosquito! Boo! Boo!!!
Friday Evening January 4th. A
real warm day this 4th of Jan-
uary has been, followed by
one of the most beautiful moon-
light nights I have ever beheld-
At 6 o'clock, a beautiful rain
came and now with the light,
fleecy, fluffy clouds and the
full moon, it is simply
heavenly. I wish that my
darling girls could see this
night -- and I wonder what they
are doing- Has precious
Miss Annapolis returned
from her Christmas outing?
Is she back once more at
her books like a dear sweet
girl? Did big Mr Charles
Wheatley meet her at the
train with another box of
Candy? You know, I rather
“take” to that boy! He cer-
tainly shows very good taste!
Our patient, a very gentleman-
ly spaniard, is doing as well
as we could expect at this
stage of his illness- He bears
his pains so patiently that one
can't help sympathizing with
him- We injected his blood under
the skin of a soldier to-day --
Saturday Morning 5th. What a very
rainy morning! and the moisture
is coming right in from the sea,
and from the north- Dear me!
I am afraid that you have
been having some bad weather
in the U.S- I almost shiver
at the idea of running into cold
weather once more- Have me
a nice hot Toddie ready when
I come, lovie, dear! Don't make
but one at a time! He! He! Ho!
Ho! Goodbye, you darling Joys!
Kisses & love & love & kisses for
my precious girls-
